questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections from the lesion shown in the image, located near the external ear. What is the most likely embryological cause of this lesion?
questions.correct_answer: A. Malfusion of 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malfusion of 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is caused by malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches , leading to a congenital sinus that may result in recurrent infections.
  • ➤ preauricular sinus
  • ➤ malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with ear trauma, swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the auricle. Which of the following is false regarding the condition shown in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to cauliflower ear

options.label: B
options.text: Spontaneous resolution occurs in most cases

options.label: C
options.text: It is caused by the accumulation of blood in the perichondrial space

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate intervention with aspiration or drainage is necessary

questions.correct_answer: B. Spontaneous resolution occurs in most cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spontaneous resolution occurs in most cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auricular hematomas require immediate aspiration or drainage , as they do not resolve spontaneously and can lead to cauliflower ear if left untreated.
  • ➤ immediate aspiration or drainage
  • ➤ not resolve spontaneously
  • ➤ cauliflower ear

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with itching and discomfort in his right ear for the past week. He also complains of mild hearing loss. On examination, the ear canal appears erythematous with white, fluffy material. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Foreign body in the ear canal

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otomycosis presents with itching, mild discomfort, and fungal debris in the ear canal (usually white, fluffy material) and is common in diabetics and immunocompromised individuals.
  • ➤ Otomycosis
  • ➤ itching, mild discomfort, and fungal debris in the ear canal

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with discharge from the ear, visual disturbances, and severe retro-orbital pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.correct_answer: C. Gradenigo Syndrome and trigeminal ganglion
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gradenigo Syndrome and trigeminal ganglion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gradenigo Syndrome is caused by petrositis, leading to retro-orbital pain (trigeminal nerve involvement), diplopia (abducens nerve involvement), and persistent ear discharge.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with right-sided ear pain for the past 4 days. He reports feeling unwell with fatigue and mild fever. On examination, you observe multiple vesicles on the tympanic membrane, external auditory canal, and concha. The patient has difficulty closing his right eye, and the right side of his face appears drooped. He also complains of hearing loss and mild vertigo. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay Hunt Syndrome)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay Hunt Syndrome)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay Hunt Syndrome) is characterized by painful vesicles on the external ear, tympanic membrane, and postauricular area, accompanied by facial nerve palsy, sensorineural hearing loss, and vestibular disturbances.
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay Hunt Syndrome)
  • ➤ facial nerve palsy, sensorineural hearing loss, and vestibular disturbances.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic man presents with severe pain in the ear and persistent otorrhea that has not responded to antibiotics. On examination, there is granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the patient exhibits facial nerve palsy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Necrotizing Otitis Externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrotizing otitis externa is a life-threatening infection of the external ear seen in diabetics or immunocompromised patients, characterized by severe ear pain, granulation tissue in the EAC, and cranial nerve palsy, requiring urgent treatment with antipseudomonal antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the location and significance of the facial recess in middle ear surgery, particularly during cochlear implantation?

options.label: A
options.text: The space between the facial nerve and the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: The space between the incus and the stapes

options.label: C
options.text: The space between the facial nerve and the chorda tympani nerve

options.label: D
options.text: The space between the cochlea and the round window

questions.correct_answer: C. The space between the facial nerve and the chorda tympani nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The space between the facial nerve and the chorda tympani nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial recess is the surgical space between the facial nerve and the chorda tympani nerve in the middle ear, providing critical access for cochlear implantation procedures.

questions.text: A patient undergoes a Rinne test with different tuning forks to assess hearing loss. The patient shows a negative Rinne test at 256Hz, a negative result at 512Hz, but a positive Rinne test at 1024Hz. Based on this, what is the approximate degree of hearing loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 30-45 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative Rinne test at 256Hz and 512Hz but a positive Rinne at 1024Hz corresponds to an approximate hearing loss of 30-45 dB.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of difficulty hearing during conversations, especially when speaking with family members in a normal setting. His hearing difficulty is less pronounced when someone speaks loudly, but he often struggles with whispers. Based on this information, what is the patient's approximate hearing threshold?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 30-60 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hearing loss in the range of 30-60 dB typically causes difficulty with normal conversation but may still allow the patient to hear loud voices or shouts.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram
questions.correct_answer: B. Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The audiogram shows bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss characterized by thresholds greater than 90 dB for both ears across all frequencies.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram in the provided image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Meniere’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease typically presents with low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss on audiogram, differentiating it from other conditions like otosclerosis (2 kHz dip), NIHL (4 kHz dip), and acoustic neuroma (trough-shaped loss).

questions.text: A patient presents with right unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Otoscopy is normal, pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows moderate sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), impedance audiometry shows Type A tympanogram, and speech discrimination scores are very poor. Based on the most likely diagnosis, what would the tuning fork test results be?

options.label: A
options.text: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear

options.label: D
options.text: Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

questions.correct_answer: A. Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acoustic neuroma , tuning fork tests show positive Rinne’s test (AC > BC) and Weber’s test lateralizes to the better ear (the contralateral side in unilateral SNHL).
  • ➤ acoustic neuroma
  • ➤ positive Rinne’s test
  • ➤ Weber’s test lateralizes to the better ear

questions.text: Identify the Audiogram and the Diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Presbycusis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbycusis presents with a classic down-sloping audiogram with high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, typically seen in the elderly due to age-related degeneration of the cochlea.
  • ➤ Presbycusis
  • ➤ down-sloping audiogram

questions.text: Identify the following sequence of otoendoscopic images from left to right.

options.label: A
options.text: Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum

options.label: B
options.text: Serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum, glomus tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Glomus tumor, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum, serous otitis media

options.label: D
options.text: Normal eardrum, glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)

questions.correct_answer: A. Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Be able to differentiate common otoendoscopic findings such as glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media, and a normal eardrum based on characteristic tympanic membrane appearances.

questions.text: Which structure is the yellow arrow pointing in the endoscopic image of left nasopharynx given below
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmüller.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fossa of Rosenmüller is an important anatomical landmark located posterior to the torus tubarius in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx and is a common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ fossa of Rosenmüller

questions.text: Which opening is present posterior to the structure marked with black arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sphenopalatine foramen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The sphenopalatine foramen is an important anatomical landmark, located posterior to the middle turbinate.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with sudden onset pain and reduced hearing for the past 2-3 days. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute otitis media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute otitis media presents with a bulging, inflamed tympanic membrane and is associated with sudden onset ear pain, fever, and hearing loss.
  • ➤ Acute otitis media

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with sudden onset pain and reduced hearing for the past 2-3 days. The otoscopic finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myringitis bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa presents as bullae on the tympanic membrane, distinguishing it from other middle ear conditions like acute otitis media or serous otitis media.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II tympanoplasty places a graft on the incus or remnant of the malleus, Type III on the stapes (columella tympanoplasty), Type IV on the stapes footplate (cavum minor), and Type V involves a fenestration operation.

questions.text: Identify the retractor depicted in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perkins retractor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Perkins retractor is a self-retaining instrument commonly used in ENT surgeries, especially for retraction of tissues during mastoidectomy.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the utricle develop?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pars superior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The utricle and semicircular ducts develop from the pars superior of the otic vesicle, while the saccule and cochlear duct develop from the pars inferior.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in lower frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Helicotrema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The helicotrema at the apex of the cochlea lies near the basilar membrane region responsible for detecting low-frequency sounds .
  • ➤ helicotrema
  • ➤ low-frequency sounds

questions.text: Mark the false statement/statements regarding Inner and Outer hair cells: Outer hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate the function of outer hair cells. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio of 1:3 respectively.

options.label: A
options.text: I, III, and IV are false

options.label: B
options.text: I, II, and III are false

questions.correct_answer: A. I, III, and IV are false
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) I, III, and IV are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Outer hair cells, arranged in 3–4 rows, modulate the function of inner hair cells, which are arranged in a single row and transmit auditory signals to the brain.

questions.text: For detecting malingering, which test cannot be used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) PTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For detecting malingering, objective tests such as OAE, BERA, and impedance audiometry are reliable, while pure tone audiometry (PTA) is a subjective test and cannot be used to detect malingering.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the function of semicircular canals?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Angular acceleration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The semicircular canals are responsible for detecting angular acceleration, while linear acceleration is sensed by the utricle and saccule. The cochlea is responsible for hearing, with the base detecting high frequencies and the apex detecting low frequencies.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of the auditory pathway: Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is: spiral ganglion → cochlear nucleus → superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be used for screening of hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Most prominent wave corresponds to the superior olivary nucleus

questions.correct_answer: C. Most prominent wave corresponds to the superior olivary nucleus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Most prominent wave corresponds to the superior olivary nucleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Waves in BERA:
  • • Wave I: Represents the auditory nerve. Wave II: Represents the cochlear nucleus. Wave III: Represents the superior olivary complex. Wave IV: Represents the lateral lemniscus. Wave V: Represents the inferior colliculus, and this is the most prominent wave used to estimate hearing thresholds.
  • • Wave I: Represents the auditory nerve.
  • • Wave I:
  • • Wave II: Represents the cochlear nucleus.
  • • Wave II:
  • • Wave III: Represents the superior olivary complex.
  • • Wave III:
  • • Wave IV: Represents the lateral lemniscus.
  • • Wave IV:
  • • Wave V: Represents the inferior colliculus, and this is the most prominent wave used to estimate hearing thresholds.
  • • Wave V:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most prominent wave in Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is Wave V , which corresponds to the lateral lemniscus , and BERA is an objective, non-invasive test commonly used for screening hearing loss.
  • ➤ Wave V
  • ➤ lateral lemniscus

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus lasting minutes to hours, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. On investigations, endolymphatic hypertension is present. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right Meniere's Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease presents with episodic vertigo , tinnitus , sensorineural hearing loss (usually low frequency) , and endolymphatic hydrops , which can be identified by an ascending slope on pure tone audiometry.
  • ➤ episodic vertigo
  • ➤ tinnitus
  • ➤ sensorineural hearing loss (usually low frequency)
  • ➤ endolymphatic hydrops
  • ➤ ascending slope

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the therapeutic maneuver?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epley's maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Epley maneuver is a therapeutic procedure used to treat Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) by repositioning displaced otoliths within the semicircular canals.
  • ➤ Epley maneuver
  • ➤ therapeutic procedure
  • ➤ Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)

questions.text: A patient presents with ear pain and sore throat. On examination, otoscopy is normal. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be the cause for ear pain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Referred ear pain in a patient with a sore throat and normal otoscopy is most commonly due to irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which supplies sensory innervation to both the pharynx and the middle ear.
  • ➤ glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) not suitable for use?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Profound sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) is effective for conductive or mixed hearing loss but cannot be used in cases of profound sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) where the cochlea or auditory nerve is severely damaged.
  • ➤ Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA)
  • ➤ conductive or mixed hearing loss
  • ➤ cannot
  • ➤ profound sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

questions.text: A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry is given. Pick the correct combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: B
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

options.label: C
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of right-sided sensorineural hearing loss , both ears will show a positive Rinne's test , and Weber's test will lateralize to the left ear (the better hearing ear).
  • ➤ right-sided sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ positive Rinne's test
  • ➤ Weber's test will lateralize to the left ear

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Ad tympanogram seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ossicular dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Type Ad tympanogram is seen in conditions with increased compliance of the tympanic membrane, such as ossicular dislocation .
  • ➤ Type Ad tympanogram
  • ➤ ossicular dislocation

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test was positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test now?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) False negative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss , the Rinne test may give a false negative result, as the patient may perceive sound through bone conduction from the opposite ear, falsely suggesting that bone conduction is better on the affected side.
  • ➤ severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ Rinne test
  • ➤ false negative

questions.text: What is the grade of TOS retraction in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Grade 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade 4 pars flaccida retraction is characterized by scutum erosion and possible destruction of the ossicles, requiring surgical intervention to prevent complications like cholesteatoma.
  • ➤ Grade 4 pars flaccida retraction
  • ➤ scutum erosion

questions.text: Identify the otoendoscopy image. The black-headed spores in this image indicate which organism growth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger otomycosis presents with black-headed spores in otoendoscopy, which are a hallmark of this fungal infection in the external auditory canal.
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger
  • ➤ black-headed spores

questions.text: Type of perforation seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subtotal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A subtotal perforation involves a large portion of the tympanic membrane, sparing the margins, and is more extensive than central perforations.
  • ➤ subtotal perforation

questions.text: What is the type and grade of retraction shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sade grade 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sade grade 3 pars tensa retraction adheres to the promontory, indicating a deeper level of retraction compared to earlier stages with adhesion to the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • ➤ Sade grade 3

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Jarjaway fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Jarjaway fracture involves the quadrilateral cartilage and is commonly seen in cases of severe nasal trauma leading to nasal deformity or septal deviation.
  • ➤ Jarjaway fracture

questions.text: Sluder’s neuralgia is due to compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sluder’s neuralgia results from the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate , leading to referred nasal or facial pain.
  • ➤ Sluder’s neuralgia
  • ➤ anterior ethmoidal nerve
  • ➤ middle turbinate

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left middle turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The middle turbinate is the second of the three nasal turbinates, located between the inferior and superior turbinates, and plays a role in regulating airflow and humidifying air entering the nasal cavity.
  • ➤ middle turbinate

questions.text: Lacrimal gland is present in which wall of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Roof

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lacrimal gland is located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit , housed in the lacrimal fossa of the frontal bone , which forms part of the roof of the orbit .
  • ➤ lacrimal gland
  • ➤ superolateral aspect of the orbit
  • ➤ lacrimal fossa
  • ➤ frontal bone
  • ➤ roof of the orbit

questions.text: What is the star marked structure in the given CT scan of nose and PNS ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sphenoid sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenoid sinus , a paranasal sinus located within the sphenoid bone, is the structure marked by a star in the CT scan of the nose and PNS, while the Onodi cell is marked by an arrow.
  • ➤ sphenoid sinus
  • ➤ Onodi cell

questions.text: In the given CT image, which structure is marked with arrow?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Haller Cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, and in the CT scan, the arrow-marked structure is a Haller cell, commonly located below the orbit and above the maxillary sinus.
  • ➤ Haller cells

questions.text: Which of the following does not require immediate surgical intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasal bone fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasal bone fractures usually do not require immediate surgical intervention and can often be delayed for up to a week to allow swelling to subside before performing the necessary reduction.
  • ➤ Nasal bone fractures

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Heimlich maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Heimlich maneuver is an emergency procedure to relieve choking by applying abdominal thrusts to expel an obstructing foreign body from the airway.
  • ➤ Heimlich maneuver

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with respect to Little's area?

options.label: A
options.text: Kiesselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.

options.label: B
options.text: It is situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum.

options.label: D
options.text: Anastomoses of 5 major arteries occur here.

questions.correct_answer: D. Anastomoses of 5 major arteries occur here.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anastomoses of 5 major arteries occur here.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Little's area , located in the anteroinferior nasal septum, is the most common site for epistaxis due to the convergence of 4 major arteries in the Kiesselbach's plexus.
  • ➤ Little's area

questions.text: Which of these options is a division related to the external carotid artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sphenopalatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenopalatine artery , a branch of the maxillary artery, is derived from the external carotid artery and supplies the nasal cavity, whereas the ethmoidal arteries are derived from the internal carotid artery.
  • ➤ sphenopalatine artery
  • ➤ external carotid artery

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on nasal packing. Sphenopalatine ligation was done, but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ligation of maxillary artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If sphenopalatine artery ligation fails to control epistaxis, the next appropriate step is to ligate the maxillary artery , as it is the major blood supply to the nasal cavity through its branches.
  • ➤ maxillary artery

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent episodes of sneezing, watery nasal discharge, nasal congestion, and itching. He mentions that these symptoms worsen in the morning and during pollen season. On physical examination, the nasal mucosa is pale and boggy. Transverse nasal crease and dark circles under the eyes are noted. Laboratory tests show elevated absolute eosinophil count (AEC) and serum IgE levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral antihistamines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for allergic rhinitis typically involves oral antihistamines or topical steroid sprays , which address the allergic inflammation and associated symptoms.
  • ➤ initial treatment
  • ➤ allergic rhinitis
  • ➤ oral antihistamines
  • ➤ topical steroid sprays

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing, particularly triggered by changes in temperature or humidity. She denies any history of allergies, and her allergy testing is negative. On examination, her nasal mucosa appears swollen but pale. Further investigation suggests that the cause of her symptoms is due to autonomic dysfunction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vasomotor rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasomotor rhinitis presents similarly to allergic rhinitis but is triggered by environmental changes and is not related to allergens , with negative allergy tests.+
  • ➤ Vasomotor rhinitis
  • ➤ not related to allergens

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with chronic nasal obstruction and foul-smelling nasal discharge. On examination, the nasal mucosa is pale and crusted, with a widened nasal cavity. She reports anosmia but denies any discomfort from the foul odor. Her medical history is unremarkable, and there is no history of leprosy or syphilis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa , merciful anosmia , and foul-smelling crusts due to secondary infections.
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis
  • ➤ atrophy of the nasal mucosa
  • ➤ merciful anosmia
  • ➤ foul-smelling crusts

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a coastal region presents with a complaint of nasal obstruction and blood-tinged nasal discharge. On examination, a polypoidal, strawberry-like mass is seen in his nasal cavity, which bleeds upon touch. He reports frequent swimming in local ponds. A biopsy confirms the presence of sporangia with spores. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with a strawberry-like mass in the nasal cavity that bleeds easily on touch, commonly seen in people with pond water exposure .
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium seeberi
  • ➤ strawberry-like mass
  • ➤ pond water exposure

questions.text: In which radiographic view is the sphenoid sinus best visualized?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pierre view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pierre view is the radiographic view in which the sphenoid sinus is best visualized.
  • ➤ Pierre view
  • ➤ sphenoid sinus

questions.text: All of the following are related to CSF rhinorrhea except:

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards

questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea typically presents with unilateral watery nasal discharge , often worsening on bending forward, and is commonly associated with trauma, halo sign, and managed with antibiotics and acetazolamide.
  • ➤ unilateral watery nasal discharge

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal cartilages is most likely to be calcified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thyroid cartilage is the laryngeal cartilage most likely to undergo calcification , due to hyaline nature, particularly with advancing age.
  • ➤ thyroid cartilage
  • ➤ calcification

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a swelling in the neck that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver and decreases on rest. On compression, a hissing sound is heard as air escapes into the larynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laryngocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A laryngocele is an air-filled cystic dilatation of the laryngeal saccule that presents with a swelling that increases with Valsalva and produces a hissing sound on compression (Bryce sign).
  • ➤ laryngocele
  • ➤ hissing sound on compression

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. During examination, it is noted that her vocal cords are paralyzed on both sides. Which nerve is most likely damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)

options.label: B
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN)

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) supplies all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid and is most likely damaged during thyroid surgeries, leading to vocal cord paralysis and hoarseness .
  • ➤ recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
  • ➤ vocal cord paralysis and hoarseness

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of lesions in the larynx:

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal granuloma, reinke oedema, vocal cyst

options.label: B
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal cyst

options.label: C
options.text: Leukoplakia, vocal cancer, polypoid corditis, vocal polyp

options.label: D
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal polyp

questions.correct_answer: D. Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal polyp
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke’s edema, vocal polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of laryngeal lesions progresses from vocal nodules (benign) to vocal cancer (malignant) , followed by Reinke’s edema (benign fluid accumulation) , and finally vocal polyps (benign lesions due to trauma) .
  • ➤ vocal nodules (benign)
  • ➤ vocal cancer (malignant)
  • ➤ Reinke’s edema (benign fluid accumulation)
  • ➤ vocal polyps (benign lesions due to trauma)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomical differences between the pediatric and adult larynx is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrowest part of the adult larynx is the subglottis.

options.label: B
options.text: The pediatric larynx has a cylindrical shape.

options.label: C
options.text: The epiglottis in adults is omega-shaped.

options.label: D
options.text: The pediatric larynx is positioned higher in the neck at the level of C1 and C2.

questions.correct_answer: D. The pediatric larynx is positioned higher in the neck at the level of C1 and C2.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The pediatric larynx is positioned higher in the neck at the level of C1 and C2.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pediatric larynx is anatomically higher (at C1-C2) and funnel-shaped, with an omega-shaped epiglottis, whereas the adult larynx is lower (C3-C6), cylindrical, and has a leaf-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding laryngomalacia?

options.label: A
options.text: Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of expiratory stridor in infants.

options.label: B
options.text: Stridor worsens when the infant is in a prone position.

options.label: C
options.text: Laryngomalacia usually resolves by the age of 2 years as the cartilages become more rigid.

options.label: D
options.text: Supraglottoplasty is the first-line treatment for all cases of laryngomalacia.

questions.correct_answer: C. Laryngomalacia usually resolves by the age of 2 years as the cartilages become more rigid.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngomalacia usually resolves by the age of 2 years as the cartilages become more rigid.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia, the most common cause of inspiratory stridor in infants, usually resolves by 2 years of age as the laryngeal cartilages become rigid.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent episodes of respiratory distress and stridor since birth. On bronchoscopy, the subglottic airway appears narrowed, and the cricoid cartilage is abnormally thickened. The patient is diagnosed with congenital subglottic stenosis. A Cotton-Myer grading of 60% stenosis is given. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Resection of the stenotic segment with primary anastomosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Endoscopic dilatation or laser excision
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Endoscopic dilatation or laser excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In congenital subglottic stenosis, endoscopic dilatation or laser excision is appropriate for Grade I and II stenosis, while Grades III and IV require tracheostomy and laryngotracheal reconstruction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness of voice for the past 2 months. On laryngoscopy, a lesion on the vocal cords is visualized. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. He is diagnosed with early-stage glottic carcinoma (T1 N0 M0). What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy (RT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early-stage glottic carcinoma (T1 N0 M0) is typically treated with radiotherapy, with conservation surgery as an option if radiotherapy fails.

questions.text: A post-COVID-19 diabetic patient presents with unilateral facial pain, loosening of teeth, and facial swelling. You suspect mucormycosis. Which investigation would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Nasal endoscopy with biopsy for histopathologic examination

questions.correct_answer: B. Nasal endoscopy with biopsy for histopathologic examination
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nasal endoscopy with biopsy for histopathologic examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasal endoscopy with biopsy and histopathologic examination is the gold standard investigation to confirm mucormycosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows blocked ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeat surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with blocked ostia and mucosal edema post-FESS, repeat surgery is indicated if medical management has failed to restore proper ventilation and drainage.
  • ➤ repeat surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of clear, watery nasal discharge, predominantly from the left nostril. He reports that the discharge increases when he bends forward and notes a sweet taste in his mouth. The patient has a history of head trauma from a motor vehicle accident two weeks ago. A physical examination shows a positive sniff test, and a handkerchief test reveals that the nasal discharge does not stiffen the handkerchief. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea typically presents with unilateral, clear nasal discharge that increases with head movement (reservoir sign) and cannot be sniffed back. It is often associated with trauma and can be confirmed with the beta-2 transferrin test or imaging studies like HRCT and MRI.
  • ➤ unilateral, clear nasal discharge
  • ➤ trauma
  • ➤ beta-2 transferrin

questions.text: A surgeon performing a thyroidectomy is carefully dissecting the structures around the pharyngeal constrictor muscles. While working between the middle pharyngeal constrictor and the thyropharyngeus (upper part of the inferior constrictor), which of the following structures is most likely to be encountered?

options.label: C
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve passes between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscles and provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords.
  • ➤ internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
  • ➤ middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscles

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, snoring, and recurrent ear infections. Physical examination reveals enlarged tonsils and features of adenoid facies. Regarding adenoid and tonsil hypertrophy, which of the following statements are TRUE? (Select the correct combination of statements) Adenoids usually disappear by 6 years of age. Adenoid hypertrophy can cause serous otitis media. Tonsillectomy is performed in the peritonsillar space. The Eustachian tube is not affected by adenoid hypertrophy. Chronic tonsillitis can present with Irwin-Moore sign. Tonsillar hypertrophy is a cause of referred otalgia. Membranous tonsillitis is exclusively caused by group A streptococcus. High arched palate can result from chronic mouth breathing due to adenoid hypertrophy. The internal carotid artery lies medial to the tonsil in the tonsillar bed. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct both Eustachian tube openings.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 5, 8, 10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy can cause nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, snoring, and ear problems like serous otitis media, while chronic tonsillitis may present with signs like Irwin-Moore sign, and both may necessitate surgical intervention if medical treatment fails.

questions.text: Regarding Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) and Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma, which of the following statements are TRUE? (Select the correct combination of statements) Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is common in adolescent males. Biopsy is recommended in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma to confirm the diagnosis. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Holman-Miller sign is associated with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma. Hearing loss in Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma is conductive type. Frog face deformity is seen in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma commonly arises from the fossa of Rosenmuller. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma commonly presents with rhinolalia clausa. Biopsy is contraindicated in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma spreads to cranial nerves 6, 3, 4, and 5 if it extends into the cranium.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 5, 8, 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is a vascular tumor seen in adolescent males presenting with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction, while Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma is a malignant tumor associated with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and conductive hearing loss, commonly presenting in patients from Southeast Asia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Peritonsillar Abscess (Quinsy) and Ludwig's Angina are true ? (Select the correct combination of statements) Peritonsillar abscess is a collection of pus between the tonsillar capsule and the superior constrictor muscle. Peritonsillar abscess is commonly managed with an incision at the midpoint of the soft palate. Hot potato voice is characteristic of peritonsillar abscess. Trismus is a key feature of Ludwig's angina. Interval tonsillectomy is performed 6 weeks after drainage of a peritonsillar abscess. Ludwig's angina is a unilateral cellulitis of the submandibular space. Dental caries are the most common cause of Ludwig’s angina. The incision for draining Ludwig’s angina is placed below the uvula. Incision and drainage are the initial treatments for both Ludwig’s angina and peritonsillar abscess. Ludwig's angina involves cellulitis of the submandibular space and is always bilateral.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5, 7, 10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess presents with hot potato voice, trismus, and uvular displacement, and requires drainage through an incision in the peritonsillar space, whereas Ludwig’s angina is a bilateral cellulitis of the submandibular space, commonly caused by dental infections, and requires a submandibular incision for drainage.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon, while performing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, has accidentally cut the parent nerve. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from the posterior semicircular canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macula of saccule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ singular nerve
  • ➤ inferior vestibular nerve (IVN)
  • ➤ posterior semicircular canal
  • ➤ saccule

questions.text: A patient while eating fish felt something suddenly stuck in her throat and came to ER. She is having a pricky sensation in her throat. She was advised an X-ray which is given below. Find the location of foreign body.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected fish bone impaction with no foreign body visible on X-ray, consider local mucosal trauma as the cause of symptoms and manage conservatively with reassurance and anti-inflammatory medications.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with unilateral hearing loss. Oto-endoscopic picture is shown below. Rinne was negative and weber lateralised to the same ear. Clinically next structure to be observed in the patient is
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unilateral serous otitis media in older adults, especially with conductive hearing loss, nasopharyngeal pathology (like nasopharyngeal carcinoma) should be ruled out with nasopharyngeal endoscopy.
  • ➤ unilateral serous otitis media
  • ➤ nasopharyngeal pathology

questions.text: Match the following surgical instruments with the surgeries for which they are typically used: Instruments: Surgeries:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A4, B3, C1, D2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Learn to correctly identify and match the Mollison Mastoid Retractor with Mastoidectomy, Dennis Browne Tonsil Holding Forceps with Tonsillectomy, Freer Elevator with Septoplasty, and Tracheal Dilator with Tracheostomy.

questions.text: Which structure is visualised in which procedure? Procedures are labelled A to D. Structures are labelled 1 to 4. Match accordingly.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A4, B1, C2, D3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Match the visualization of vocal cords with indirect laryngoscopy, laryngeal ventricles with direct laryngoscopy, adenoids with nasopharyngeal examination, and the middle turbinate with diagnostic nasal endoscopy. This knowledge is crucial for medical students preparing for residency to understand the scope and focus of various ENT diagnostic procedures.
